Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: A consistent pattern is identified where a 'case' could be defined based on the 'Window' attribute. A case groups all activities related to the same file or application window until the user switches focus or closes the window.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: By observing the log entries, it is inferred that when a 'FOCUS' action occurs on a new 'Window,' it indicates the start of a new case, implying user attention has shifted to a different task.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: From the structure of the log and the action types, activity names were deduced. For example, 'FOCUS' on a document suggests 'Open Document,' and 'TYPING' indicates 'Edit Document.'

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: It is hypothesized that sequences ending with 'CLOSE' suggest task completion for a case. This assumption is corroborated by the lack of further actions within the same 'Window.'

Name: Validation - PE
Text: The proposed case grouping logic is tested by applying it to overlapping FOCUS actions. Testing confirms that cases are correctly segmented based on user interaction context.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: Naming conventions for activities like 'Reply to Email' and 'Send Email' rely on keywords in the 'Action' field. While effective here, this may not handle edge cases where action descriptions are inconsistent.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: From temporal patterns, it is inferred that activities such as 'Save Document' often follow sequences of 'Edit Document,' reflecting user's workflow.

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Revisiting early assumptions, adjustments are made to treat certain SWITCH actions as transitions between cases rather than part of existing cases. This improves coherence.
